{{Use Australian English|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox MP |honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] |name = Ephraim Clarke |honorific-suffix = |image = Ephraim Clarke.png |image_size = 140px |office2 = Member of the [[Western Australian Legislative Assembly|Legislative Council]]
of [[Western Australia]] |constituency2 = [[South-West Province (Western Australia)|South-West Province]] |term_start2 = 21 August 1901 |term_end2 = 15 April 1921 |predecessor2 = [[William Spencer (settler)|William Spencer]] |successor2 = [[Francis Willmott]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1846|8|21|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Australind, Western Australia|Australind]], [[Western Australia]], Australia |death_date = {{Death date and age|1921|4|15|1846|8|21|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]], [[Western Australia]], Australia |party = [[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist]] |alma_mater = }} '''Ephraim Mayo Clarke''' (21 August 1846 – 15 April 1921) was an Australian politician who was a member of the [[Western Australian Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] of [[Western Australia]] from 1901 until his death, representing [[South-West Province (Western Australia)|South-West Province]]. He was a minister in the second government of [[George Leake]]. Clarke was born in [[Australind, Western Australia|Australind]], in Western Australia's [[South West (Western Australia)|South West]] region. He initially worked on his father's property at Australind, but later farmed at his own property, near [[Harvey, Western Australia|Harvey]]. In 1874, Clarke moved to [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]], where he was a storekeeper and warehouse owner. He was eventually elected to the [[City of Bunbury|Bunbury Municipal Council]], and served four periods as mayor of Bunbury (in 1888, from 1894 to 1897, from 1899 to 1900, and in 1908). Clarke entered parliament at a 1901 Legislative Council by-election, which had been caused by the death of the sitting member, [[William Spencer (settler)|William Spencer]] (a former mayor of Bunbury). In December 1901, just months after being elected, he was made a [[minister without portfolio]] in the [[Second Leake Ministry|Leake ministry]]. However, George Leake died in July 1902, and Clarke was not retained in [[James Ministry|the new ministry]] formed by [[Walter James]]. After his initial election, Clarke was re-elected four more times (in 1902, 1908, 1914, and 1920), eventually joining the [[Nationalist Party of Australia|Nationalist Party]].[http://www.parliament.wa.gov.au/parliament/library/MPHistoricalData.nsf/(Lookup)/CE8CE30EC184E640482577E50028A56C?OpenDocument Ephraim Mayo Clarke] – Biographical Register of Members of the Parliament of Western Australia. Retrieved 4 June 2016. He died in Bunbury in April 1921, aged 74.[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/27961541 "DEATH OF MR. E. M. CLARKE."], ''[[The West Australian]]'', 16 April 1921. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clarke, Ephraim}} [[Category:1846 births]] [[Category:1921 deaths]] [[Category:Australian people of English descent]] [[Category:Mayors of places in Western Australia]] [[Category:Members of the Western Australian Legislative Council]] [[Category:Nationalist Party of Australia members of the Parliament of Western Australia]] [[Category:People from Bunbury, Western Australia]] [[Category:Western Australian local government politicians]]
